channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SGF-198] BeanCurrentlyInCreationException when injecting async-event-queue to a Gemfire replicated region
item.description:
Getting BeanCurrentlyInCreationException when injecting a async-event-queue to a region such as the following.

Error:
org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCurrentlyInCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'async-event-queue': Requested bean is currently in creation: Is there an unresolvable circular reference?

Gemfire region configuration:
<gfe:async-event-queue id="async-event-queue"
batch-size="10"
persistent="true"
disk-store-ref="gemfirePersistenceStore"
maximum-queue-memory="50"
parallel="true"
batch-conflation-enabled="true"
batch-time-interval="3"
dispatcher-threads="4"
disk-synchronous="true"
order-policy="KEY">
<gfe:async-event-listener>
<bean class="some.AsyncCacheEventListener"/>
</gfe:async-event-listener>
</gfe:async-event-queue>

<gfe:partitioned-region id="policy" persistent="true" disk-store-ref="gemfirePersistenceStore" disk-synchronous="true"
recovery-delay="6000">

<gfe:async-event-queue-ref bean="async-event-queue"/>
</gfe:partitioned-region>
item.summary: BeanCurrentlyInCreationException when injecting async-event-queue to a Gemfire replicated region

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The XML configuration meta-data provided in the description of this bug is inconclusive for reproducing the BeanCurrentlyInCreationException.

I have just succeeded in creating a SDG XML configuration file that bootstraps a peer GemFire Cache node setting up a Disk Store (dataStore) used by both a persistent Async Event Queue (q1) as well as persistent Partitioned Region (ordersRegion). I also have another non-persistent Async Event Queue (q2) and Replicate Region (customersRegion) configured, where both Regions reference the persistent Async Event Queue (q1) in my test and the Replicate Region (customersRegion) also references the non-persistent Async Event Queue (q2). Since the Partitioned Region (ordersRegions) is persistent, it too refers to the Disk Store (dataStore).

The snippet of XML configuration meta-data for my test is...


  <util:properties id="peerCacheConfigurationSettings" location="classpath:gemfire.properties"/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:cache properties-ref="peerCacheConfigurationSettings"/>
 
 
 
  <bean id="asyncEventListener" class="org.springframework.data.gemfire.cache.asyncqueue.TestAsyncEventListener"/>
 
 
 
  <gfe:disk-store id="dataStore" auto-compact="true" compaction-threshold="75" queue-size="50" max-oplog-size="10" time-interval="600000">
 
    <!--gfe:disk-dir location="./gemfire/disk-store-files/" max-size="50"/-->
 
  </gfe:disk-store>
 
 
 
  <!-- Focal point of JIRA issue SGF-198 -->
 
  <gfe:async-event-queue id="q1"
 
                         name="QueueOne"
 
                         persistent="true"
 
                         disk-store-ref="dataStore"
 
                         disk-synchronous="true"
 
                         maximum-queue-memory="50"
 
                         parallel="true"
 
                         batch-conflation-enabled="true"
 
                         batch-size="10"
 
                         batch-time-interval="3"
 
                         dispatcher-threads="4"
 
                         order-policy="KEY">
 
    <gfe:async-event-listener ref="asyncEventListener"/>
 
  </gfe:async-event-queue>
 
 
 
  <gfe:async-event-queue id="q2" name="QueueTwo">
 
    <gfe:async-event-listener ref="asyncEventListener"/>
 
  </gfe:async-event-queue>
 
 
 
  <gfe:replicated-region id="customersRegion" name="Customers">
 
    <gfe:async-event-queue-ref bean="q1"/>
 
    <gfe:async-event-queue-ref bean="q2"/>
 
  </gfe:replicated-region>
 
 
 
  <gfe:partitioned-region id="ordersRegion" name="Orders" persistent="true" disk-store-ref="dataStore" disk-synchronous="true">
 
    <gfe:async-event-queue-ref bean="q1"/>
 
  </gfe:partitioned-region>

The test configuration meta-data closely follows the configuration meta-data provided in the description.

While the BeanCurrentlyInCreationException is certainly possible with an unresolvable, circular reference (usually with constructor injection), it is not occurring with the above snippet of XML configuration meta-data from the description.

Please see the Spring documentation on Dependency resolution process and specifically, the side bar on "Circular dependencies" for more details.

Eddy- Another thing you can try would be to strip out all non-essential bean definitions from the Spring configuration and add them 1 (or a few) at a time until you run into the Exception. This is tedious and cumbersome, but should help isolate and determine which beans or combination of beans are causing the issue.

Attaching example test app (persistentasynceventqueue-test.zip) with the Spring configuration described in the comments from Thursday, September 12, 2013, illustrating the successful creation of a disk-store, both persistent and non-persistent async event queues as well as both persistent and non-persistent regions using the event queue(s).
I found that if there is any Spring Bean dependency, that exception occurs. For instance, let say in your TestAsyncEventListener you inject Bean1 @Autowired Bean1.

Eddy-

I was able to reproduce your issue using constructor injection in my TestAsyncEventListener bean to another Service bean in the application context as you said. However, this problem is easily resolvable by resorting to either instance "field" or "setter" injection and using a bean lifecycle callback, post construction, to ensure the proper initialization of the TestAsyncEventListener bean as I have demonstrated in the revised example test app.

While this does not guarantee the same object initialization safety semantics as a constructor, it is a common pattern in Spring and a good alternative, especially when beans are stateless (or rather Thread-safe).

I need to research this a bit further, though, as I am not sure whether this is a problem caused by Spring Data GemFire's XML namespace configuration and initialization or the Spring configuration in general.

Typically, BeanCurrentlyInCreationExceptions are caused by circular references using constructor injection. So, in my example test app, I created a CustomerService bean that injects a CustomerDao with a reference to the /Customers Region bean. The CustomerService bean gets injected into the constructor of the TestAsyncEventListener, thereby causing the exception. In fact, it is the only place "constructor" injection is apparent in it's use.

When I comment out the constructor and resort to either instance field or setter injection, the example test app gets configured properly with no exceptions and the test passes. However, I was a bit surprised when I commented out the /Customers Region bean reference in my DAO, thereby breaking the "cycle", that I ran into the BeanCurrentlyInCreationException again when still using constructor injection in my TestAsyncEventListener bean.

At any rate, the use of "field" or "setter" injection solves the problem. If you have further issues, let me know.

Thanks.
Updated example test app reproducing the issue.

Further investigation and testing revealed that the AsyncEventListener bean declaration and definition from the context configuration meta-data was being injected into the constructor of the AsyncEventQueueFactoryBean by the AsyncEventQueueParser, which ultimately was causing this problem, and explains the BeanCurrentlyInCreationException after I broke the cycle described above. Fix in-progress.
This issues will be resolved for the 1.3.3.RELEASE.
Bug fixed and PR merged for the 1.3.3 release.
